Everyone wants health care reform but this plan is lacking many policies that solve the problem. The biggest cost driver is defensive medicine-ask any doctor. This plan does nothing to solve that problem. Our current tort system is a travesty and is unjust. Who would design a system that takes 5 years for a payout, spends 60% of the dollars on lawyers and administration and doesn't reduce malpractice. As a doctor who has been dragged through this process I can tell you it does not deal with all of the facts nor have I been sued for anything other than bad outcome. At the end of the 5 years, when the court has ruled in our favor we win nothing but 5 years of sleepless nights and legal bills paid for by our patients with health care dollars. In addition, the out of court settlements are never counted and last year you paid for a 75,000 dollar bruise from surgery because it was cheaper to settle than defend a case that was not malpractice but rather a known and recognized risk of surgery. There has to be a better, less costly system to protect patients but our legislators are supported by trial lawyers or are trial lawyers and the status quo is maintained. If true tort reform occurred we could better spend our health care dollars and more would have access. Do you want the status quo and is it sustainable?

For younger readers like myself who grew up with the Times and continue to value the paper, the Kouwe incident is notable mostly for what it says about the paper. I do not condone what Kouwe did—it was plagiarism and his termination was warranted—but in his sanctimonious analysis of the incident, Mr. Hoyt does much to reveal the anachronistic shackles that the old guard continues to impose on the Times. One paragraph from his piece encapsulates this perfectly:

"Everyone I talked with at The Times agreed that the practices described by Kouwe and Posner were unacceptable. 'If you are writing your own story, you shouldn’t be downloading this stuff,' said Jack Lynch, the news editor of DealBook. 'That’s asking for trouble.' Amen."

“Amen”?!? Plagiarism is unacceptable. But to condemn the process by which Posner and Kouwe did their background research is to reveal a fundamental misunderstanding of how journalism is practiced today as well as a prejudice against online sources as valid texts. There were obviously flaws in the way Kouwe and Posner organized their research, but to say they “shouldn’t be downloading this stuff” is to reveal yourself as a geriatric crank. I suppose in Mr. Lynch's view, the process would have been less reprensible—though the result no less so—had Mr. Kouwe consulted books rather than this nefarious “stuff” they found on the intertubes. Consulting other texts is called research; that the “text” in question originated online is immaterial.

In aligning himself with Lynch and other old-Timesers, Hoyt ignores what should be his priority: initiating a more clear-eyed investigation of the paper’s evolution. Has the combination of staff cutbacks and the faster pace of the web eroded quality? Should there be a qualitative difference between items published in the Times’s blogs and those published in the paper? Is a more rigorous editing process needed for online? Are old standards too expensive or impractical to uphold?

But while Hoyt includes vagueries about “conversations worth having” with regard to online and “more oversight” for Dealbook, what he’s really interested in is a full accounting of Kouwe’s offenses because, as always, his main purpose is to draw attention to the paper’s august reputation and sacrosanct standards, in this case by casting out an unworthy. But such self-congratulation solves nothing; Mr. Kouwe is at fault here, certainly, but magnifying his fault doesn’t exculpate the institution.

I'm actually rather sympathetic to the writer's claim here.  Unintentional plagiarism seems very likely in a time-pressured blog writer's world.  Since we treat most blogs as quick, off-the-cuff thoughts and analysis, not final, well-crafted, fully supported articles, perhaps we could be more forgiving of 1st or even 2nd violations.  Just require prominent, long-lasting apologies and full crediting of the original writer.

First and foremost, Mr. Sorkin is the editor of DealBook. Mr Hoyt should have mentioned one other hat Mr. Sorkin wears: The Celebrity One. As a result, the Times takes another journalistic hit.

Everyone wants to have his cake and eat it too. Scientology preaches that that is possible.

The nice thing about organized religions is that really anyone can join... in but here and in other cases, we can see it can be very hard to get out once you are in. On the other hand, we don't have Jihad from scientologists-- at least not yet.

I personally object to the not-for-profit status of these clubs, although as a historian of the middle ages, I appreciate the achievements of the Catholic Church which provided government (bishops were the heads of their communities)and a certain stability during a period when things could have been worse. (The idea of government is to promote peace so that all can prosper.) Not that there wasn't infighting within the church then -- Investiture Controversy anyone?)
The only mystery here is why do some people believe in any of this Scientology nonsense.

I feel awful for people raised in the church. To have to suffer like this, spending their intimidated lives in the service of a fraud. How difficult it must be to come to terms with this. Let's hope they did do some good somewhere, and can get beyond this to enjoy a fuller life. Good luck guys.

For those interested, the SYDA foundation is also a cult. This is the ashram that appeared in the book "Eat, Pray, Love". SYDA uses very similar techniques to Scientology to recruit, control, and get money. There are also rich and famous people involved -- one off the top of my head is Melanie Griffith.

SYDA has the elitist thing going on: only the cream of the crop are allowed into the inner circle, and by golly, you do everything you can to stay there. It also caters to the rich people mentality of "if it costs a lot, it must be good".

I was a part of this cult for a short time. My partner, who turned me on to it, had been in it for more than twenty years. When I finally started to look up the history of this organization I was really getting into, I found websites of people who had left SYDA, and their reasons were very similar to those who have left Scientology. My heart sank. I knew I had been duped. When I told my partner about my discoveries, he said it was too bad that all those people were trying to tear down SYDA. Multiple people. Over decades. He hardly even looked at the evidence I had found.

For anyone reading this who is a part of this organization, please google "leaving SYDA".

Now is the time to relate how L. Ron. (Doc Methuselah) Hubbard imapacted on my 1940s Manhattan youthful Pulp Fiction addictions. Astounding Science Fiction was my monthly hit of hits. Weird Tales with its H.P. Lovecraft Mythos( imagine Cthlhuu transformed into Xenu) was small potatoes compoared with the muscular Fascism of Robert A. Heinlein or the Null-A (non-Aristotelian),pro-gun fantasms of A.E. van Vogt, or the reseting of Gibbons' "Decline and Fall" into Isaac Asimov's Foundation Series. Imagine my chagrin, when in late 1951, my monthly nickel bag (25 cents) was rewarded by 125 pages of fictional non-fiction baptized Dianetics. John W. Campbell's (Who Goes There - later the "Look to the skies" movie) dithyrambic Prelude to this "Brave New World" impelled me to two or three readings of L.Ron's turgid exsposition. It was a no go and took the wind out of the hitherto bravura Sci-Fi offerings of A.S.F.
Thank you L. Ron Hubbard for closing the curtain on a adolescent addiction engrams and all.

It is hard to explain because a few years ago, the leaders pretty much kicked alot of people out and had already moved to other houses in Gainesville, Ga.
There is a website called whathappenedtodeerfield.wordpress.com... that gives the stories of many people of this cult, about the leaders that are still operating. or look up Grant Clarke, or Gregg Hake or Energetix or Anakiri or Spa on Green Street in Gainesville, GA. these are a few of their businesses now and two of the leaders.
Just remember that people join these cults not knowing it's a cult. They bring people in and brainwash and make you feel good and it sure is interesting how they did it.
